title: Is pursuing a graduate in a humanities subject (eg. English, Political Science, History, Economics, etc) really a waste of time? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends on you. But probably. Look, nobody wants to tell you the truth: most people don’t get to study academic things for a job. Colleges don’t want to tell you because they want you to pay them, and because they believe in the Ivory Tower. Professors don’t want to tell you because they are the Ivory Tower, and their field of study benefits when there are more people educated in it to choose from for the next generation of professors. High School teachers don’t want to tell you because they’ve all been forced to study under the same professors, and have all been trained not to compromise a kid’s self esteem by telling them “that’s not a good idea,” but instead “you can do whatever you want to do.” Parents don’t want to tell you because they want their children to believe in their dreams, and when they grew up a degree meant something independent of what was actually studied. A generation ago, 7% of young people went to college. Now, it’s closer to 40%. Even if all those original 7% went on work in academia, do you think that the share of jobs in academia have gone up from 7% to 40%?Absolutely not. So what does a degree in a humanities subject get you in terms of a future career? Very little. Don’t get me wrong, there are still benefits. A broader, deeper understanding of the world around you, of human history, of human experience, is a wonderful thing.But…how much will you pay for that experience? Will you go into debt? Thinking about it like a product you purchased, will the amount you spend make sense for anything that doesn’t help you advance your lifestyle, or better care for your family, like a car or a home? At the prices being charged by universities these days, the product they provide only makes sense in terms of investing in your career. And there is only one way that getting a degree in most humanities subjects will be worth that cost: if you go into academia, and become a professor yourself. Are you bright enough for that? Are you disciplined enough for that? Keep in mind that it’s going to be harder for you to “make it” than it was for your professors, because you are competing with far more fellow humanities majors than they are for scarcely more jobs. It is possible you are one of those who are indeed destined for such a career. I could have done it. But it turns out, I value my family’s stability more than going back to school to get my Ph.D, a conclusion I came to after a couple years in the work force. They told us we could all be whatever we wanted to be. Even that we shouldn’t aim for anything else. They were wrong.

If you already joined then no problem. It is not waste of time. If you have really interest in Humanities subjects then you can make your career with them. It can be Economics or History, if you mater these subjects and learn these subjects in very depth you can be a Economist and with History subject you can become teacher (also you can go for Research and Development)
